medium: Opaque watercolor, gold, and silver on paper
title: Bhairavi Ragini in Attitude of Renunciation with Ladies-in-Waiting
marks:
Inscription

on back, in black ink: untranslated
text:
The art of painting in central India and Rajasthan is deeply rooted in Indian tradition. It takes inspirations from Indian epics, religious texts, Hindu myths, Sanskrit love poems, folklore, and, as is the case here; musical themes called ragamalas and raginis.

This painting illustrates the Bhairavi Ragini, a female musical mode that typically depicts a princess within a shrine performing puja (a Hindu prayer ritual) before a lingam, which is a symbol of the god Shiva. The princess is dressed in ascetic's garb in the yellow color of renunciation while accompanied by ladies-in-waiting who assist her with the ritual. A miniature bull Nandi, the vehicle of Shiva, is seated in the foreground.

Jodhpur was one of several important Rajasthani schools of court sponsored painting. These royal ateliers generally avoided deep pictorial space, nuanced color, and naturalistic drawings in favor of bright decorative colors often enhanced with gold and silver leaf. Compositions are usually flat and stylized, often lacking natural proportions.
